item.title: Obama Administration Considers Arming Syrian Kurds Against ISIS
item.media:description: Kurdish Y.P.G. fighters last year during a battle for Tel Tamer, Syria, at their combat outpost on the outskirts of the city.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: The major policy shift could speed up the offensive against the Islamic State but also sharply escalate tensions between Turkey and the United States.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: U.S. Officials Say Russia Probably Attacked U.N. Humanitarian Convoy
item.media:description: The bombed trucks: “Just when we think it cannot get any worse, the bar of depravity sinks lower.”
item.description: United Nations officials were dumbfounded by the airstrike, which occurred after the Syrian military declared that a partial cease-fire was over.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT, MICHAEL R. GORDON and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Russia Denies Any Role in Deadly Convoy Attack in Syria
item.media:description: Bombed aid trucks in Syria on Tuesday. The destruction of the aid convoy dealt a serious blow to attempts by the United States and Russian to work together on Syria.
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Some in Russia accuse the Syrian government, while others blame America. The Obama administration says it holds Russia responsible.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Isle of Man, Flourishing in Britain’s Shadow, Faces Pivotal Vote
item.media:description: Douglas, the capital of the Isle of Man, which is not technically part of the United Kingdom but is instead a crown dependency. Residents will go to the polls on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: The British vote to leave the E.U. and changing views on topics like abortion are forcing the crown dependency to confront big issues in elections on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: U.N. Signals That Climate Deal Has Backing Needed to Enter Force
item.media:description: Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, backstage on Tuesday at the annual session of the General Assembly.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: Haste on the Paris accord is driven at least in part by the looming American election, with Donald J. Trump, the Republican candidate, vowing to reject the pact.
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: How Bad Off Is Oil-Rich Venezuela? It’s Buying U.S. Oil
item.media:description: The Cardon refinery, which belongs to the Venezuelan state oil company PDVSA, in July in Punto Fijo, Venezuela.
item.description: Oil accounts for half the government’s revenues, but profits have evaporated amid a drop in global prices, forcing Venezuela to seek help from a nemesis: the United States.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY and CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: Canada Agrees to Talks on Extradition Treaty With China
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada at the United Nations General Assembly in New York this week. He has denied that Canada made any concessions to China for its release of a Canadian missionary who had been detained for more than two years on espionage charges.
item.description: An announcement nearly coinciding with the deportation of a Canadian missionary held in China on spy charges raises criticism by human rights advocates.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: ‘Lula,’ Brazil’s Ex-President, Will Be Tried on Corruption Charges
item.media:description: Former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil in March. Charges against Mr. da Silva involve claims that he and his wife illegally received about $1.1 million in improvements and expenses from a construction company for a beachfront apartment.
item.description: A judge accepted corruption charges against Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, setting the stage for a trial of one of the region’s most influential politicians.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Turpan Journal: In a Parched Corner of Xinjiang, Ancient Water Tunnels Are Running Dry
item.media:description: A Uighur man drove his donkey and cart past a well that draws water from an underground karez in Turpan, China.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The karez channels that bring water from the mountains to the farmers of Turpan are under threat, a victim of global warming, oil drillers and industrial-scale agriculture.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: It’s Not Like Hollywood: Why U.S. Airstrikes Go Awry
item.media:description: A hospital run by Doctors Without Borders in Kunduz, Afghanistan, was in ruins after it was bombed in an errant American airstrike in 2015.
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.description: Military officers and experts say that almost all mistaken American strikes over the years have come down to two main reasons: faulty intelligence and battlefield confusion.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: North Korea Says It Has Tested a New Long-Range Rocket Engine
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, center, the North Korean leader, at the testing of a new long-range rocket engine at the Sohae Space Center on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The ground test of a new rocket engine used to put a satellite into orbit followed the North’s nuclear test on Sept. 9, its fifth since 2006.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Allister Sparks, South African Journalist Who Challenged Apartheid, Dies at 83
item.media:description: Allister Sparks, second from right, in Cape Town in 2011 with Bono, the U2 frontman, left; Archbishop Desmond Tutu, right; and Archbishop Tutu’s daughter Mpho, who co-wrote a biography of him with Mr. Sparks.
item.description: As the editor of The Rand Daily Mail, Mr. Sparks exposed a covert government propaganda campaign that led South Africa’s president to resign.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: Looming Transition Ignites Deadly Clashes in Congo
item.media:description: The headquarters of the Union for Democracy and Social Progress, an opposition party, in Kinshasa, the Democratic Republic of Congo, on Tuesday after it was attacked.
item.media:credit: Junior D. Kannah/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: At least 25 people from opposing sides of a political divide have been killed in a burst of violence in Kinshasa in the past two days.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Burundi Killings Could Ignite Wider African Crisis, U.N. Report Warns
item.media:description: The body of a domestic worker who was shot by the police lay in the back of a truck in Musaga, a neighborhood of Bujumbura, the capital, in January.
item.description: Investigators said the government was responsible for the “vast majority” of abuses and urged international action to contain the country’s violence.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: ‘Moment of Truth’ in Syria as John Kerry Urges Restoration of Cease-Fire
item.description: The United States Secretary of State told the United Nations Security Council that continuing with the agreed cease-fire was the only way forward.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Chemical Accidents in China Have Killed Nearly 200 This Year, Report Finds
item.media:description: Cars and buildings last year after an explosion at the site of what had been a warehouse storing thousands of tons of chemicals in Tianjin, a city in northeastern China.
item.description: The Greenpeace report suggested that regulation of the industry remained lax, a year after a disaster in the city of Tianjin prompted calls for more oversight.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: In Appeal to Voters, Muslim Brotherhood in Jordan Soft-Pedals Religion
item.media:description: A Jordanian woman with her son registered her name to cast her ballot at a polling station in Amman for parliamentary elections.
item.description: Forgoing the more radical language of Islamists in other parts of the region, the Brotherhood emphasized bread-and-butter concerns for Tuesday’s election.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: Ousted Critic of Rodrigo Duterte Decries ‘New McCarthyism’ in Philippines
item.media:description: Senator Leila de Lima at a session of the Philippine Senate on Tuesday. She was stripped of her post as chairwoman of the Senate Justice Committee.
item.description: Leila de Lima said that she was the victim of a campaign to end her inquiry into the president’s possible role in extrajudicial killings.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK and FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Erdogan, at United Nations, Defends Turkey’s Move Into Syria
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey in August. He said the Turkish army’s incursion into Syria had helped stabilize the border area in a speech to the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday.
item.description: Turkey’s president said the army had helped bring peace to the Syrian-Turkey border region and urged the General Assembly to find a political solution to the war.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Istanbul Journal: On Istiklal, Istanbul’s Champs-Élysées, Symbols of a City’s Malaise
item.media:description: A tram ran along Istiklal Avenue below where customers sipped coffee and tea at a cafe last month in Istanbul. Istiklal, Turkey’s most famous avenue, is facing a sharp decline in business.
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.description: There seems to be no end to Turkey’s troubles, from a coup attempt to spillover from the war in Syria. All of that is felt these days on Istiklal Avenue.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: 5 Cuban Volleyball Players Convicted of Rape in Finland
item.media:description: Members of Cuba’s national volleyball team who were accused of rape at court in Tampere, Finland, in August.
item.description: The athletes, who were given prison terms, had traveled to the country for a tournament in July.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and MARI-LEENA KUOSA

item.title: Rights Groups Criticize Israeli Inquiry Into 2014 Gaza War
item.media:description: A displaced Palestinian family camped amid the destruction in Gaza in 2014, after a cease-fire with Israel came into effect. About 2,200 Palestinians were killed during the war that year, more than half of them civilians. On the Israeli side, 73 people were killed, most of them soldiers.
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.description: One organization called the legal process for handling misconduct allegations a “facade” intended to try to stave off a war crimes investigation.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Greeks Appeal for Aid After Fire Damages Refugee Camp
item.media:description: Migrants amid the remains of a tent on Tuesday after a fire at the Moria migrant camp on the Greek island of Lesbos.
item.description: The blaze, which started inside the main Moria camp of Lesbos, destroyed 50 homes and dozens of tents, driving about 4,400 migrants into nearby fields, aid workers said.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: China Announces Inquiry Into Company Trading With North Korea
item.media:description: Dandong, in the Chinese province of Liaoning, is a major hub for trade with North Korea.
item.description: The conglomerate deals in materials that researchers in South Korea and the United States say can be used in the production of nuclear weapons.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Dandong Hongxiang Industrial Development Company Ltd

item.title: Thai Court Finds British Labor Activist Guilty of Defamation
item.media:description: Andy Hall, a British defender of migrant rights, outside the Bangkok South Criminal Court on Tuesday after the court found him guilty of criminal defamation and breaching computer laws in Thailand.
item.description: Andy Hall was sentenced to three years in prison in connection with his work on a report that accused a Thai company of violating its workers’ rights.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: The Interpreter: 15 Years Into Afghan War, Americans Would Rather Not Talk About It
item.media:description: American soldiers during Afghan National Army training at Camp Bastion in Helmand Province, Afghanistan, in March. This year’s presidential campaign has hardly touched the war in Afghanistan.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Cautious presidential candidates and a weary public are part of a bipartisan silence over the war, which is still costing American lives and hundreds of billions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Abroad in America: Donald Trump, the Unsinkable Candidate
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump, the Republican nominee, at a campaign event in Colorado on Saturday.
item.description: Many of Mr. Trump’s remarks would have seriously damaged other candidates, but he has remained popular in spite of accusations of racism and graft.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Sinosphere: Once a Voice of Young China, Han Han Stakes Out a Different Path
item.media:description: Han Han, writer, film director and racecar driver.
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.description: After the publication of a new collection of essays, Han Han, at one time China’s most popular blogger, explains why he’s maintaining a lower profile online.
item.dc:creator: KAROLINE KAN

item.title: Justin Trudeau’s Message to U.N.: ‘We’re Canada and We’re Here to Help’
item.description: In his first address to the General Assembly, Mr. Trudeau pledged to work with other countries on migrants, the environment and economic disparity.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Obama, in Farewell to U.N., Paints Stark Choices for Unsettled World
item.media:description: President Obama on Tuesday after addressing the United Nations General Assembly, the last such speech of his tenure.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: In the last General Assembly address of his presidency, Mr. Obama was focused as much on the American presidential election as on his legacy.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Theresa May Makes Her Debut as the Voice of Britain
item.description: In her first foreign policy speech as prime minister, Mrs. May reassured the United Nations that Britain remained a responsible international player.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: François Hollande, France’s President, Urges Action on Climate and Syria
item.description: Addressing the United Nations General Assembly, he called on the gathered countries to put the Paris climate deal into action and to end Syria’s bloody war.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Brazil’s New President, Michel Temer, Defends Impeachment of Dilma Rousseff
item.description: Mr. Temer told the United Nations General Assembly that the proceeding showed “absolute respect for the constitutional order,” but he declined to address corruption scandals.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: The Interpreter: Straightforward Answers to Basic Questions About Syria’s War
item.media:description: Musa, a 25-year-old Kurdish sniper, on top of a building in the destroyed town of Kobani, also known as Ain al-Arab, in Syria in January 2015.
item.description: Tracking the toll is not difficult, but understanding how and why the conflict evolved is far more complicated – and important.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: What in the World: A Site to Help Get Wedding Bells Ringing and Ringing and Ringing
item.description: A British entrepreneur saw a business opportunity in matching up married men who want to add wives, and single women who’d be happy sharing a spouse.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: What in the World: A Paris Shop Turns On the Charm, and South Koreans Swoon
item.media:description: Tourists shopping at Pharmacie Monge in Paris last month.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: Pharmacie Monge’s cosmetics and a nod from a blogger drew South Korean tourists in. The hiring of Korean-speaking employees kept them coming in droves.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: What Hugo Chávez Tells Us About Donald Trump
item.description: For both figures, TV, performance and reality shows are at the center of their idea of politics and government.
item.dc:creator: ALBERTO BARRERA TYSZKA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How a Russian Fascist Is Meddling in America’s Election
item.description: The antidemocratic ideas of Ivan Ilyin are guiding the Kremlin’s interference in U.S. presidential politics.
item.dc:creator: TIMOTHY SNYDER

item.title: Editorial: Behind Mr. Putin’s Easy Victory
item.media:description: Voters went to the polls in Stavropol, Russia, on Sunday.
item.description: Russia appears to have returned full circle to a pseudo-parliament whose only function is to give a semblance of legitimacy to an authoritarian ruler.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has also been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
